title: Key Events in Genesis
description: A sequence of the major events in the Book of Genesis, tracing the foundational stories of creation, sin, and the patriarchs.

cards.description: God creates the heavens, earth, and humanity, establishing the world and its order.
Adam and Eve disobey God, introducing sin and death into the world. Their expulsion from Eden marks the beginning of humanity’s struggles.
Sin escalates as Cain murders Abel, showing the rapid spread of corruption. This event highlights the consequences of the Fall.
God sends a flood to judge a wicked world, sparing Noah and his family. The ark and rainbow covenant reset humanity’s story.
Humanity rebels by building a tower to the heavens. God scatters them with different languages, shaping the nations.
God calls Abram to leave his home, promising to make him a great nation. This begins the story of the patriarchs.
God formalizes His promise to Abram, renaming him Abraham. This covenant lays the foundation for Israel’s identity.
Hagar bears Ishmael to Abraham, a result of impatience for God’s promise. This birth foreshadows future conflict.
Sarah gives birth to Isaac, the long-awaited child of promise. This fulfills God’s covenant with Abraham.
God tests Abraham by commanding Isaac’s sacrifice, only to provide a substitute. This proves Abraham’s faith.
Twins Jacob and Esau are born, and their rivalry begins with Esau trading his birthright for a bowl of soup. This sets up future trickery.
Jacob deceives Isaac to receive Esau’s blessing, a pivotal act that aligns with God’s earlier promise, though achieved through cunning means.
God appears to Jacob in a dream of a ladder stretching between heaven and earth, with angels ascending and descending. God renews the covenant in this vision. This affirms Jacob’s role in the story.
After Jacob works for seven years to marry Rachel, Laban deceives Jacob into marrying Leah first, extending Jacob’s labor. This mirrors Jacob’s own deceptive past.
Rachel, the wife whom Jacob loved most, gives birth to Joseph, who will become a pivotal figure. His arrival marks a turning point for the family.
Joseph’s brothers sell him into slavery out of jealousy due to their father's favoritism. This betrayal sets him on a path to Egypt.
With God's favor, Joseph rises from prisoner to Pharaoh’s second-in-command through Joseph's wisdom, integrity, and interpretation of dreams. This prepares for a coming famine.

A severe famine drives Joseph’s brothers to Egypt for grain, leading to a dramatic reunion with the brother they betrayed. Joseph forgives them and orchestrates their relocation to Goshen, where Jacob’s family settles.
